content.description:
The sit to High Water Mark.  Left hand high on three-finger undercling/sidepull, right hand on good edge in the horizontal seam.  Sloping feet on either side of the arete.  

  Two moves gain the start of the stand, finish to top. 

  Green in the Beta Photo
Really obvious 45Â° overhang on hidden side of the boulder. Start on obvious edge, use any number of feet, go to intermediate or even make the huge move straight to the lip. Easy mantle to finish.

Sit with left hand on good crimp in horizontal, right on much smaller crimp just next to it. With feet down left, make long move to starting hold of Bedtime, find footing for difficult match, and continue to top. 

  Pink in the Beta Photo

On the arete nearest the stream, start with right hand on jug at chest height and left on sloper rail. A quick move to crystals left or right brings you to the sloping top.  

  Good feet abound up high, but don't pop off or risk a very serious ankle buster, even from a relatively low height. (Spotter may also end up in the drink.) 

  Yellow in the Beta Photo

Pull on at the bulb above the Dirt Burglar Project. Throw a heel on the lip out left, press it out and stand to the top. 

  A great introduction to mantling.
content.protection: Pad the rock below the bulb, or spot tightly.
content.location: First climb you come to on the approach.

content.description:
The "opposite" of Dismantle, and a full grade harder. 

  Pull on the jug rail just above and left of Dirt Burglar project. Throw right heel on the big bulb out right, pull up, mantle, and reach into the vertical seam if you need extra balance.  Stand to top.   

  A great introduction to mantling.  (Do Dismantle first.)

Realistically, this problem is a squeeze job, as the Jug start for High Water Mark is only about 6 inches above the sloping pinch...   Still quite possibly the most enjoyable line here.  

  Start sitting on the left side of the face, directly right of the pointy rock.  Right hand in the good crimp, left hand on the best part of the seam out left.  Tough move to a sloping pinch on the arete, right up to your choice of slick crystals, and left to another pinch on/just below the arete.  Easier terrain to top. 

  The first three moves are distinctly difficult to link.
content.protection: Until someone shifts that massive pointy rock, several pads are necessary.

content.description: Starts in the middle of the face on obvious good edges.    Pop left to flexing flake, match, top out. Feet are not always obvious.
content.protection: Best landing on the boulder. One pad? No pad?
content.location:
Right side of vertical face. 

  Blue in the Beta Photo

content.description:
A lovely 12-footer with climbing on two faces, sitting adjacent to a tiny year-round stream. 

  Secluded, short.
